timeline.bodyText:
Rather than overriding this method in tests, it would be better to pass in a Consumer<Integer> shutdownFunction to the constructor (ie prefer delegation over inheritance).  You can pass a mock in tests and System::exit in production.
You will likely need two constructors for DepositCommand - a noarg one that passes System::exit and one that accepts the consumer that tests can use.

timeline.bodyText:
Two issues here:

It's vital that we write the keys to output before sending the deposit transaction.  Otherwise if we fail somewhere we've just burned a lot of ETH and lost the keys forever.
Since the logic for writing keys has become more complex we should create a KeyWriter interface with 2 separate implementations - one that writes YAML to a PrintStream (used for all unencrypted output) and one that writes to a keystore for encrypted output.

timeline.bodyText: This isn't the right approach.  If we're outputting to STDOUT, we need to make sure logging is either disabled or sent to STDERR.  Otherwise people who run this tool in real life will get corrupt output.
timeline.author: ajsutton

replies.bodyText:
It's because of the limitation of "testcontainer" docker API we are using that captures whole of standard/error output. A more better approach, which I tested, is to mount the "keys" file with --output-path and read that file after running the command. However, in Windows environment this usually cause an issue because we would have "share" the host location via docker preference. In another project of ours, we used user's home folder and create a temp directory there which can be mounted to docker container, I wonder if we can use same approach.
Last, but not least, is that I can remove the "info" logging that I introduced so that it only outputs the yaml keys on std out.
replies.author: usmansaleem

replies.bodyText:
It's not really docker related - if we're saying we'll output the content to STDOUT, we should only output the content to STDOUT but the logs are going there as well (they don't go to STDERR by default).  We can configure test containers to capture STDOUT and STDERR separately if need be.
I suspect just removing the log messages is probably the simplest approach though.

replies.bodyText: Removed additional logging for "yaml keys on standard out" mode.

replies.bodyText:
Two possible approaches:


Separate options.  So you'd have --validator-password-file and --validator-password-env if neither of those is specified, use the interactive prompt.


A single option that works out how to interpret the arg (feeling like this is going to be confusing, so leaning towards option 1).  So not specifying the option or --validator-password with no arg uses an interactive prompt.  --validator-password env:SOME_VAR would read from an environment var (the env: prefix is what tells us it's an env var) and --validator-password <any-arg> reads from a file (assuming  doesn't start with env:).

replies.bodyText:
I have introduced mutually exclusive ArgGroup so that picocli handles these errors automagically. I do have to extract out subcommands by converting methods to standalone classes to make ArgGroup work (I believe PicoCli has a bug where ArgGroup doesn't work if methods are used as subcommands). I have also changed the --encrypt-keys to --encrypted-keystore-enabled and we now run in interactive mode to obtain passwords if none of the non-interactive password options are specified. The ArgGroup also allows to provide sub-section heading. e.g.
./teku validator generate --help

teku validator generate [OPTIONS]

Description:

Register validators by generating new keys and sending deposit transactions to
an Ethereum 1 node

Options:
  -a, --amount=<GWEI>       Deposit amount in Gwei (default: 32000000000)
  -c, --contract-address=<ADDRESS>
                            Address of the deposit contract
  -e, --encrypted-keystore-enabled=<true|false>
                            Create encrypted keystores for validator and
                              withdrawal keys. (Default: true)
  -h, --help                Show this help message and exit.
  -n, --number-of-validators=<NUMBER>
                            The number of validators to create keys for and
                              register
  -o, --output-path=<FILE|DIR>
                            Path to output file for unencrypted keys or output
                              directory for encrypted keystore files. If not
                              set, unencrypted keys will be written on standard
                              out and encrypted keystores will be created in
                              current directory
  -p, --private-key=<KEY>   Ethereum 1 private key to use to send transactions
  -u, --node-url=<URL>      JSON-RPC endpoint URL for the Ethereum 1 node to
                              send transactions via
  -V, --version             Print version information and exit.
Non-interactive password options for validator keystores:
      --validator-password-env=<ENV_VAR>
                            Read password from environment variable to encrypt
                              the validator keys
      --validator-password-file=<FILE>
                            Read password from the file to encrypt the
                              validator keys
Non-interactive password options for withdrawal keystores:
      --withdrawal-password-env=<ENV_VAR>
                            Read password from environment variable to encrypt
                              the withdrawal keys
      --withdrawal-password-file=<FILE>
                            Read password from the file to encrypt the
                              withdrawal keys

Teku is licensed under the Apache License 2.0

replies.bodyText: @arash009  yes, both validator keystore and withdrawal keystore options are independent of each other, so validator keystore's password can come from environment variable for instance, while withdrawal's password can be read from file. However, due to mutually exclusive mode, you can either specify --validator-password-env or --validator-password-file but not both.
